awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Hand-held assistive mobility device for the visually impaired using sensors to feel obstacles from a distance and track their movements
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a hand-held assistive mobility device for the visually impaired.  The Center for Disease Control (CDC) estimates that approximately 12 million people over the age of 40 suffer from visual impairment in the United States. Vision impairment and loss of sight are among the top 10 disabilities for individuals over the age of 18 and can have a substantial social and economic toll including, but not limited to, significant loss of productivity and diminished quality of life. Further, the annual economic impact of major vision problems in those 40 and older is estimated to be $145 billion. The proposed device holds the potential to significantly improve mobility, accessibility, and quality of life for the millions of people with no or low-vision that currently use an assistive mobility device such as the widely used “white cane.” The technology also offers potential benefits to people working in low-visibility or disaster conditions, such as emergency first-responders or military personnel.

This I-Corps project is based on the development of a hand-held device that uses remote sensing technology to control a dynamic tactile display on the hand, allowing the visually impaired to detect and classify obstacles in their environment sooner and more broadly than is possible using current assistive technology devices.  Unlike existing technologies that involve touching or poking items with a white cane or rely on the individual to follow auditory cues, this device may enable individuals to feel the presence of obstacles and targets from a distance, including the relative location of multiple obstacles and being able to track the relative movements of nearby obstacles and targets.  The proposed technology is an extension of research into optimized graphical displays of information derived from Sound Navigation and Ranging (SONAR) and Light Detection and Ranging (LIDAR)-based sensor systems. People in low-vision situations may be better equipped to rapidly process and exploit multi-channel spatial information when it is delivered via the hand instead of the ear. The proposed technology exploits the natural active-sensing behaviors used by humans when they reach out to explore their environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The goal of this project was for a team of students to learn how to commercialize a new remote sensing technology developed in our biosonar lab as part of their participation in the NSF I-Corp Program during summer of 2021. Through participation in the training program, students learned how to develop a business thesis and evaluate the potential for their new product through customer discovery interviews and meetings with topical experts and potential industry partners.

The team (Visioglove) tested the hypothesis that our remote-sensing glove would provide more safety and independence to visually-impaired users by allowing more efficient navigation than currently possible with existing assistive mobility devices.  Although the team considered several possible target customer groups, they settled upon blind and severely visually-impaired as the most likely early adopters of this new technology. There are approximately 6 million visually-impaired people in the United States that rely upon assistive mobility devices to get around.  There are three main assistive device options currently in wide use, 1) white canes, 2) guide dogs, and 3) cellphones and WiFi-dependent navigation apps. Our business thesis proposed that our product filled a niche between canes and guide dogs. Canes only offer information about obstacles within a meter of the user, while guide dogs offer greater information about distant obstacles but at the cost of autonomy. Guide dogs are expensive, difficult to maintain, and are not available to the majority of visually-impaired people.  Our product would offer the ease of a cane but the extended sensing range of a guide dog (for example, guide dogs can see omcoming traffic or recognize obstacles from a distance, which makes navigation more efficient). 

Potential customer interviews revealed that our initial design was too complicated, too delicate, and too expensive for the anticipated users.  This led us to re-imagine the product to be simpler and more robust, with a focus on providing middle-distance information to aid navigation without overloading the user with a complicated interface. The remodeled device looks like a flashlight, but uses LIDAR technology to map the space ahead of the user and translates that information into a rotary tactile display in the hand. Instead of a spatial map as originally conceived, the new device translates distances into the positions of 4 rotating rings in the palm. Ring positions encode distances up to 10 meters with 1 cm precision. The device is used like a white cane, but gives the user fast, precise distance information over a much broader range than possible with a cane.  This facilitates navigation by making it easier to find doors, hallways, and the best routes around large obstacles (i.e. construction barriers on sidewalks). Furthermore, the device can relay information about the movement of targets and obstacles, such as cars and other people.  Lastly, white canes attract unwanted attention: our device does not reveal that the user is handicapped, which was a frequent complaint about white canes.

Through our interviews with potential customers and experts in the field, we learned that the proposed product is viable. We validated a sizeable customer segment (roughly 1 million US citizens with severe visual impairment) that desire an option better than white canes and more accessible than guide dogs. Key constraints that came out of the customer discovery process were costs, reliability and intuitive use (can't be too complicated). 

Broader Impacts: This project had two entrepreneurial leads: The graduate student entrepreneurial lead (EL) was subsequently offered a job in industry and importantly, the employer commented that his participation in I-Corps was a significant factor in their decision to hire him. The post-doc (underrepresented minority) that also served as co-EL accepted a new faculty position at Virginia Tech University (Dept of Neuroscience) and intends to include commercialization as a central component of his academic research plan.  The new product is still under development and being tested, with hope that it will someday find its way to market and benefit millions of blind and visually-impaired people.  This invention has the potential to make it significantly easier for blind people to move about and navigate by foot in busy places.  This can make it easier for them to secure and maintain employment, affords greater independence, and improve overall quality for life.
